The Digital Nomad Era Is Upon Us

9–5 is irrelevant. Your office is no longer needed. Welcome to a new way of viewing (and visiting) the world.

Kate Smith is no ordinary woman.

Two years ago she quit her job and bought a one-way plane ticket to Prague.

Turns out the Czech Republic was the first stop on an elite program called Remote Year — a magical experience where 75 Digital Nomads get together for a year and move to a different city every month. Sound like a dream? Well, it was more than that to Kate. It was a reality.

When pondering her drastic leap into the unknown, she had this to say.

“The time is never right.”
“You have to make it the right time. For me, I push my boundaries and limits in so many ways. When I started my Nomad journey, it wasn’t a financially comfortable situation for me to be in, but I did it anyways. Most people would’ve said ‘I’m gonna save up for six months to a year.’
I think that people need to realize it’s your responsibility to make it happen. Nobody is going to make it happen for you.”

Wait a second — how did Kate get to this point? What kind of crapshoot was she involved in that led her to denounce corporate life and embrace digital nomad-ism?

A terrible job? Crappy boss? Bills?

Actually, none of that. She was living the life she always dreamed of.

“I was living downtown in the city, and working as a Project Manager at an Ad Agency. That’s when things changed for me. It was everything I wanted but I remember being in the condo that I was renting and thinking: This is everything I’ve ever wanted, why don’t I feel happier?
It was at that point that I realized, I was working to live, to work to live. It was a never ending cycle and a cycle that wouldn’t allow me the opportunity to travel.”

If you didn’t already guess, Kate’s pretty smart. What’s really crazy about her journey is how sure she was of her path in college and early adulthood. Unlike many reading, she knew exactly what she wanted to do and had no problem getting it upon graduation.

Kate Smith
“When I was in college I really enjoyed it. I was really involved. I was pretty certain I knew what I wanted to do to be honest. I had a lot of friends who didn’t know what they wanted to do, and landing that job at the Advertising Agency was kind of my dream.”

Then all hell broke loose? Fire and brimstone? Apocalypse-level doom?

No. She worked as a Project Manager for three years and slowly realized this wasn’t the life she wanted.

I’m trying to show that Kate’s story isn’t ordinary. She got everything she wanted. She did well in college, at her internship, and had no problem landing a job. She worked hard and realized a dream. That’s definitely something to aspire to for certain people.

What I’m really saying is there’s probably a few reading who are about to go through this, or are going through this. They’re unfulfilled. They got exactly what they wanted, but it’s not making them happy.

What do you do then?

“For me I had to re-explore my passions. I was living a corporate lifestyle and I didn’t know what I actually enjoyed doing anymore. I never had “free time”. I would just work, come home, eat dinner, go to sleep and do it all over again.
I thought to myself, ‘What do I like to do as a person?’ So I signed up for Jiu-Jitsu, Spanish classes…”
